sub-heading:
Revised Guidelines for the Ongoing Centrally Sponsored Scheme
FEBRUARY, 2008

National Tiger Conservation Authority
Ministry of Environment & Forests
Government of India
title: Project Tiger

content:
Ministry of Environment & Forests
Government of India
title: National Tiger Conservation Authority

content:
Project Tiger is an ongoing Centrally Sponsored Scheme of the Ministry of Environment and Forests. The revised guidelines incorporate the additional activities for implementing the urgent recommendations of the Tiger Task Force, constituted by the National Board for Wildlife, chaired by the Hon’ble Prime Minister. These, interalia, also include support for implementing the provisions of the Wild Life (Protection) Amendment Act, 2006, which has come into force with effect from 4.09.2006.
The activities are as below:

(i) Antipoaching initiatives
(ii) Strengthening infrastructure within tiger reserves
(iii) Habitat improvement and water development
(iv) Addressing man-animal conflicts
(v) Co-existence agenda in buffer / fringe areas with landscape approach
(vi) Deciding inviolate spaces and relocation of villages from crucial tiger habitats within a timeframe by providing a better relocation package, apart from supporting States for settlement of rights of such people
(vii) Rehabilitation of traditional hunting tribes living in and around tiger reserves
(viii) Providing support to States for research and field equipments
(ix) Supporting States for staff development and capacity building in tiger reserves.
(x) Mainstreaming wildlife concerns in tiger bearing forests outside tiger reserves, and fostering corridor conservation in such areas through restorative strategy involving local people to arrest fragmentation of habitats.
(xi) Providing safeguards / retrofitting measures in and around tiger reserves and tiger bearing forests for wildlife conservation.
(xii) Strengthening the infrastructure of National Tiger Conservation Authority at the Centre.
(xiii) Carrying out independent monitoring and the evaluation of tiger reserves.
(xiv) Establishment and development of eight new tiger reserves.
(xv) Provision of project allowance to all categories of staff working in tiger reserves.
(xvi) Providing residential amenities to facilitate basic education to children of frontline field staff posted in tiger reserves.
(xvii) Providing assistance to States for fostering ecotourism to benefit local people.
title: Introduction

content:
"Project Tiger" was launched in April, 1973 with the objective “to ensure maintenance of a viable population of Tigers in India for scientific, economic, aesthetic, cultural and ecological values, and to preserve for all times, areas of biological importance as a national heritage for the benefit, education and enjoyment of the people”.

The Project has been successfully implemented, and at present there are 28 Tiger Reserves in 17 states, covering an area of 37761 sq. km. Apart from above ‘in principle’ approval for creation of eight new Tiger Reserves has been accorded. The selection of reserves was guided by the need to conserve unique ecosystem/habitat types across the geographic distribution of tigers in the country.

Project Tiger is an ongoing Centrally Sponsored Scheme, which is continued, in the XIth five-year Plan. Conservation of endangered species and their habitat, strengthening and enhancing the Protected Area Network, control of poaching, monitoring, research and ensuring people’s participation in Wildlife Conservation have been accorded high priority in the National Wildlife Action Plan and the Wildlife Conservation strategy, 2002.
title: Project Tiger Objectives

content:
During present plan period, 100% Central Assistance is being made available to States for expenditure on all non-recurring items; for recurring items, the Central Assistance is restricted to 50% of the expenditure, while the matching grant is provided by the Project States. The activities / field inputs under Project Tiger, interalia, include : (Non recurring) strengthening of protection, deployment of armed squads in tiger reserves, creating basic infrastructure for management, roads, wireless, civil works, habitat development, augmenting water resources, compensatory ameliorative measures for habitat restoration, eco-development, village relocation, use of Information Technology in crime detection, establishment of a digitized database in Tiger Reserves having collaborative linkage with Project Tiger Directorate in the GIS domain, monitoring and evaluation of tiger reserves, monitoring of habitat status, carrying out All India Estimation of Tigers, Co-predators and Prey animals in the GIS domain with the state of art technology, continuous monitoring of tiger populations in various tiger range states (tiger reserves and other forest areas outside tiger reserves), fostering wildlife viewing for tourists in Tiger Reserves, providing compensation to villagers for human deaths/livestock depredation by carnivores in tiger reserves, staff welfare measures, providing 'Project Allowance' to all categories of staff working in Tiger Reserves, establishment of veterinary facility, and fostering research / research projects relating to tiger conservation, replacement and purchase of new vehicles for existing and new Tiger Reserves to ensure staff mobility.
(Recurring) creation / deployment of local work force for patrolling/barriers, habitat improvement, providing salt licks, water facility, fire protection measures, maintenance of various items, publicity and extension and legal assistance.
title: Past Funding Pattern and Activities

content:
The Government of India launched “Project Tiger” to promote tiger conservation, recognizing its significance beyond state boundaries.

Management of forests and wildlife is primarily the responsibility of individual states.

The states handle:
*Field implementation
*Protection and management in designated reserves
*Matching grants for recurring expenses
*Deployment and salaries of field staff/officers

The Project Tiger Directorate provides technical guidance and funding support.
title: Project Tiger: Conservation Beyond State Boundaries

content:
Implementation of Project Tiger highlighted the need for a statutory authority with legal backing.

A Task Force was set up based on the recommendations of the National Board for Wild Life.

Recommendations included:
*Strengthening Project Tiger with statutory and administrative powers
*Creating the Wildlife Crime Control Bureau
*Submitting an annual report to Parliament
*Addressing concerns of local people
title: Need for a Statutory Authority

content:
*Reinvigorating the constitution of governance.
*Strengthening efforts towards protection of tiger, checking poaching, convicting wildlife criminals and breaking the international trade network in wildlife body parts and derivatives.
*Expanding the undisturbed areas for tiger by reducing human pressure.
*Repair the relationship with local people who share the tigers habitat by fielding strategies for coexistence.
*Regenerate the forest habitats in the fringes of the tigers protective enclaves by investing in forest, water and grassland economies of the people.
title: Urgent Recommendations of the Task Force

content:
Tiger Reserves face ecological disturbances and other problems.

Fragmentation of habitats occurs due to:
*Overuse of forest habitats
*Conflicting land uses leading to habitat loss

Significant village populations with large cattle numbers cause:
*Ecological degradation through grazing
*Disturbances like temples and commercial entities
*Man-animal conflicts, resulting in mortality
title: Challenges Faced by Tiger Reserves

content:
Several constraints affect field implementation, including:

*Delayed release of Central Assistance to States
*Staff vacancies
*Ageing of field staff
*Lack of capacity building initiatives
*Weak enforcement and monitoring of protection work

Greater commitment and vigilance from States are required. Field administration needs capacity building and supervision.
title: Constraints Affecting Field Implementation

content:
Urgent need to strengthen the Central Government level (Project Tiger Directorate).

Involvement of Parliament is required for review and guidance.

Importance of involving:
*Chief Ministers of States
*Strengthening field administration
*Building a participatory base including local people's interests
title: Strengthening the System

content:
Project Tiger converted into a statutory authority (NTCA) via the Wild Life (Protection) Amendment Act, 2006.

NTCA addresses ecological and administrative concerns for tiger conservation by:
*Providing a statutory basis for protection of tiger reserves
*Strengthening institutional mechanisms for ecologically sensitive areas and endangered species
*Enforcing guidelines for tiger conservation
*Monitoring compliance
*Placing motivated and trained officers as Field Directors
*Facilitating capacity building and staff development
title: NTCA: A Statutory Authority

content:
The Wild Life (Protection) Amendment Act, 2006 came into force on September 4, 2006, and the NTCA was constituted on the same date.

Despite efforts, the tiger remains endangered due to:
*Habitat loss
*Revenge killings
*Demand for body parts in the illegal international market

Continuance of Project Tiger is crucial to address threats.
title: NTCA's Impact

content:
Three key imperatives necessitate a 'project mode':

1. Focused approach to prioritize actions for tiger conservation
2. Eliciting support from local stakeholder communities
3. Ensuring necessary infrastructure for protection and management

Conservation of tiger has ecological national significance.

The Government of India provides funding and technical guidance through the Centrally Sponsored Scheme of Project Tiger.
title: Key Imperatives in Tiger Conservation

content:
Tigers are present in the forests of seventeen states in India, including their protected areas / tiger reserves.

The distribution and density of tigers vary due to ecological and human reasons like:
*Forest cover
*Terrain
*Natural prey availability
*Undisturbed habitat
*Managerial protection efforts

Tigers are indicators of a healthy ecosystem. Their conservation benefits all other species. Investments are justified.
title: Tiger Distribution and Density

sub_heading:
Activities & Additionalities Supported 
Under the Revised Centrally Sponsored Scheme of Project Tiger
title: Ongoing Activities

content:
The anti-poaching operations in Tiger Reserves are site specific.

The following activities would form part of the protection strategy:
*Deployment of anti-poaching squads
*Establishing and maintaining patrolling camps/chowkis and deployment of camp laborers
*Organizing vehicular patrolling (Tiger Protection Force)
*Establishing and maintaining wireless network
*Organizing surprise raids with local police
*Ensuring special site-specific protection measures during monsoon ('Operation Monsoon')
*Deployment of ex-army personnel / home guards
*Deployment of local workforce for patrolling
*Procurement of arms and ammunition
*Procurement/maintenance of elephant squads
*Rewards to informers
title: Anti-Poaching Activities (Ongoing)

sub-heading: Focus on Strengthening Infrastructure, Habitat and Community Engagement
title: Project Tiger: Key Activities

content:
Legal support for defending court cases.
Procurement of vehicles, boats.
Procurement field gear, night vision device.
title: 4.1 Legal Support & Procurement

content:
Ongoing activity, non-recurring for new civil works, recurring for maintenance.

Activities include:
Civil Works (staff quarters, family hostels, office improvement, patrolling camp, house keeping buildings, museum, culverts).
Maintenance/creation/upgradation of road network.
Maintenance/creation of wireless tower.
Maintenance/creation of fire watch tower.
Maintenance/creation of bridges, dams, anicuts.
Maintenance/creation of firelines/firebreaks.
Maintenance/creation of earthen ponds.
Procurement/maintenance of vehicles (Gypsy, Jeep, Truck, Tractor).
Habitat improvement works.
Procurement of hardware, software / GIS.
Procurement of compass, range finder, GPS, camera traps.
Procurement of satellite imageries for management planning.
Map digitization facility for management planning.
title: 4.2 Strengthening Infrastructure in Tiger Reserves

content:
Ongoing, recurring activity.

Includes: weed eradication, removal of gregarious plant growth from grasslands, grass improvement, water retention structures.

Increases forage and browse values for wild animals.
title: 4.3 Habitat Improvement and Water Development

content:
Ensuring uniform, timely compensation for human deaths due to wild animals, livestock depredation by carnivores, crop depredation by wild ungulates.
Compensation for crop loss is a new component (non-recurring).

Involves:
Payment of compensation for cattle lifting, death of human beings and crop depredation due to wild animals.
Creation of crop protection structures.
Procurement/deployment of traps, cages to catch problematic animals.
Procurement of tranquilizing equipments, rescue vehicles and drugs.
title: 4.4 Addressing Man-Animal Conflict

content:
The above initiatives are extremely important to avoid as well as redress the “park-people” interface conflicts.

Crop depredation supported as per prevailing State norms, in the delineated buffer area (Section 38V, Wild Life (Protection) Act, 1972, amended in 2006).
title: Importance of Addressing Park-People Conflicts

content:
Landscape approach/sectoral integration/ecologically sustainable development programme/livelihood options/eco-tourism.
New activity in tiger reserves where buffer not yet notified (non-recurring).

Fringe areas have corridor value, and ecological sustainability is crucial.

Delineation of buffer zone aims to:
Providing ecologically viable livelihood options to local stakeholders, reducing dependency on forests.
Conserving forest area through restorative inputs involving local people for habitat supplement to wild animals moving out of core areas.
title: 4.5 Co-existence Agenda in Buffer/Fringe Areas

content:
Forest Survey of India has conducted a comparative assessment of forest cover status of outer fringe areas (up to 10 km).

States must delineate the fringe/buffer area around core zones.

Submit a Tiger Conservation Plan (Section 38 V, Wild Life (Protection) Amendment Act, 2006) to ensure wildlife conservation and address livelihood issues.
title: Buffer Zone Delineation & Conservation Plans

content:
New activity, non-recurring.

Urgent need to launch rehabilitation for denotified tribes/tribes involved in traditional hunting around tiger reserves/corridors.

Tribes include: Behelias, Ambalgars, Badaks, Mongias, Bavariyas, Monglias, Pardhi, Boyas, Kaikads, Karwal Nat, Nirshikaris, Picharis, Valayaras, Yenadis, Chakma, Mizo, Bru, Solung and Nyishi.

Targeting around 5,000 families under NTCA initiatives.

Package should be site-specific, consultative, with livelihood options.
title: 4.6 Rehabilitation for Traditional Hunting Tribes

content:
Wages for foot patrolling for wildlife protection.
Providing agricultural land with irrigation.
Basic health care.
Housing and related community welfare inputs.
Basic education facilities.

Consideration of past experiences in settling denotified tribes (e.g., by the Salvation Army) is required.
title: Rehabilitation Package Components

content:
Ongoing, non-recurring.

All India tiger estimation has resulted in a permanent monitoring protocol for field units.

Phase-I data collection protocol should be adopted for day-to-day monitoring.

Assistance provided for field-oriented research and equipping staff with GPS, camera traps, night vision, range finder, hardware, and software.

Tiger reserves required to carry out day-to-day monitoring using GIS for “forecasting” in wildlife protection.
title: 4.7 Research and Field Equipments

content:
Ongoing, non-recurring.

Includes:
Capacity building/training.
Providing project allowance and special incentives.
Specialized training in GIS, anti-poaching operations.
Specialized training in jurisprudence and wildlife forensics.
Study tours for appraisal of good practices in other reserves.
Dissemination workshops.
Specialized training in park interpretation.
Specialized training in management planning.

Enhances field staff skills for crime detection and related skills.
title: 4.8 Staff Development and Capacity Building

content:
Deciding inviolate spaces for wildlife and relocation of villagers from core or critical tiger habitats in Tiger Reserves within a timeframe and settlement of rights.
Settlement of rights is a new activity, non-recurring.

The Wild Life (Protection) Act, 1972, and the Scheduled Tribes and Other Traditional Forest Dwellers (Recognition of Forest Rights) Act, 2006, require rights of people to be modified and resettled for providing inviolate spaces to tiger/wild animals.
title: 4.9 Inviolate Spaces and Relocation of Villagers

sub-heading: Addressing Wildlife Concerns and Habitat Fragmentation
title: Tiger Reserve Relocation and Conservation

content:
Relocation requires compensation, including rights settlement under CSS.
Section 24 of the Wild Life (Protection) Act, 1972, allows acquisition of rights in land for Sanctuaries (Section 18) or National Parks (Section 35).
Sub-section 2 authorizes the Collector to acquire land/rights, making compensation for immovable property a statutory requirement for modifying/settling rights.
title: Statutory Requirements and Compensation

content:
Tiger ecology research indicates that a minimum population of breeding tigresses needs an inviolate space of 800-1000 sq km to maintain a viable population of 80-100 tigers.
Tigers are an “umbrella species,” ensuring viable populations of co-predators, prey, and forest, thus ensuring ecological viability.
Maintaining inviolate core areas is ecologically imperative for the survival of source populations of tigers and other wild animals.
title: Ecological Imperative: Inviolate Core Areas

content:
A new package for village relocation/rehabilitation is proposed, aligned with the National Rehabilitation and Resettlement Policy, 2007.
Two Options:
Option I: Payment of Rs. 10 lakhs per family, with no Forest Department involvement in relocation.
Option II: Forest Department carries out relocation/rehabilitation from the protected area/tiger reserve.
title: Proposed Relocation/Rehabilitation Package

content:
In Option I (Rs. 10 lakhs per family), the District Magistrate ensures villagers rehabilitate themselves with the money.
A mechanism involving handholding, preferably by external agencies, should be ensured.
A considerable portion of the amount is deposited in the beneficiary's name in a nationalized bank for income through interest.
title: Option I: Direct Payment & Monitoring

content:
In Option II, the following package is proposed (per family) at the rate of Rs. 10 lakhs per family:
(a) Agriculture land procurement (2 hectare) and development: 35%
(b) Settlement of rights: 30%
(c) Homestead land and house construction: 20%
(d) Incentive: 5%
(e) Community facilities: 10%
title: Option II: Forest Department Relocation Package

content:
The relocation process is monitored/implemented by two Committees:
State Level Monitoring Committee:
(a) Chief Secretary (Chairman)
(b) Secretaries of related departments (Members)
(c) State Principal Chief Conservator of Forests (Member)
(d) Non-official members of respective Tiger Conservation Foundation (Members)
(e) Chief Wildlife Warden (Member-Secretary)
District Level Implementing Committee:
(a) District Collector (Chairman)
(b) CEO (Member)
(c) Representative officials from PWD, Social Welfare, Tribal Department, Health, Agriculture, Education, Power & Irrigation (Members)
(d) Deputy Director of the Tiger Reserve/PA (Member Secretary)
title: Relocation Process: Monitoring Committees

content:
Cost norms are indicative, allowing flexibility for State/site-specific situations.
Adjustments can be made between components and families based on requirements.
Relocated villages receive priority for eco-development and local development through convergence of District level schemes.
title: Flexibility and Priority for Development

content:
Labour oriented works in the relocation process are preferably implemented through the relocated villagers.
If resettlement is on forest land, access to forest resources is granted through the village level committee and Gram Sabhas.
The District Administration facilitates fair price shops, education, and health centers near the relocated site.
title: Livelihood and Access to Resources

content:
"Handholding" is ensured through the forest department with ongoing ecodevelopmental inputs and district administration involvement.
Help from competent independent agencies may be sought.
Relocated villagers receive priority for livelihood options from the protected area.
If relocation costs exceed Rs. 10 lakhs per family, the State Government covers the extra cost.
title: "Handholding" and Livelihood Options

content: The relocation process is open-ended, depending on State performance.
title: Open-Ended Relocation Process

sub_heading: Mainstreaming wildlife concerns in tiger bearing forests and fostering corridor conservation through restorative strategy involving locals to arrest fragmentation of habitats (new activity) (non recurring)
title: Corridor Conservation

content:
Forests connecting Tiger Reserves/Protected Areas have tigers and other wild animals.
No current Scheme addresses wildlife concerns in these areas, where restorative and protective inputs are needed.
The Wild Life (Protection) Amendment Act, 2006, addresses corridor areas.
This involves:
Redressing man-animal conflict
Capturing problematic/aberrant wild animals
Monitoring of wild animals
Antipoaching operations
Habitat improvement measures.
title: Addressing Wildlife Concerns in Corridors

content:
Communities near National Parks, Sanctuaries, and Tiger Reserves suffer crop depredation by wild herbivores.
This is exacerbated by dependence on single annual rain-fed crops with low productivity.
This issue is a major cause of man-animal conflicts around Tiger Reserves.
title: Mitigating Man-Animal Conflict

sub-heading: A review of conservation efforts and future plans for Tiger Reserves in India.
title: Project Tiger Initiatives

content:
Human-wildlife conflict is a significant challenge, particularly around Tiger 
Reserves and Protected Areas. It hinders enlisting local support for wildlife 
conservation.

Section 11 of the Wildlife (Protection) Act allows for the killing of wild animals 
causing damage, but this is often opposed by local communities due to religious 
sentiments. Trapping and translocation are not always feasible or cost-effective.

The situation necessitates adequate compensation to stakeholder communities 
around Tiger Reserves for recurring losses. This support is aligned with State norms 
and Section 38V of the Wild Life (Protection) Act, 1972 (amended in 2006).
title: Addressing Human-Wildlife Conflict

content:
Many Tiger Reserves are impacted by infrastructure such as roads, railways, and 
high-tension electric lines. Electrocution poses a mortality risk to wild animals.

Site-specific safeguards and retrofitting measures are crucial to mitigate these risks. This initiative aims to support such measures in the interest of wildlife conservation.
title: Safeguards for Wildlife Conservation

content:
This initiative focuses on providing basic infrastructure and Project Tiger 
Headquarter expenditure for consultancy and continuous monitoring of tigers, 
including those outside tiger reserves.

Key aspects include:

*   Creating office space for the National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA).
*   Establishing a GIS outstation laboratory at the Wildlife Institute of India.
*   Carrying out All India Tiger Estimation and monitoring.
*   Supporting research work and special studies.
*   Conducting International/National Workshops.
*   Arranging for data entry and analysis.
title: Strengthening Infrastructure and Monitoring

content:
Independent monitoring of tiger reserves is conducted using 45 parameters by 
a panel of experts, based on the IUCN format. Reports are peer-reviewed by the IUCN and presented before the Parliament.

This process continues to be refined and implemented during the XIth Plan period.
title: Independent Monitoring and Evaluation

sub_heading: Establishing and developing eight new Tiger Reserves to enhance conservation efforts and increase the total area under Project Tiger. This involves both recurring and non-recurring activities tailored to each reserve's needs.
title: Expanding Tiger Reserves

content:
Project Tiger employs a holistic ecosystem approach, focusing on maintaining the stability of the ecosystem by fostering all trophic levels in the food chain.

This ensures an ecologically viable tiger population at the apex of the food chain. Community pressures on forests are increasing, leading to fragile tiger habitats. Protected areas/Tiger Reserves are becoming like isolated 'islands'.

Empirical evidence indicates that isolated reserves lose species rapidly due to ecological insularization. Fragmentation, degraded forest cover, dislocated prey-predator ratios, and lack of eco-development initiatives further aggravate the situation.
title: Holistic Ecosystem Approach

content:
The Steering Committee of Project Tiger recommended including new Tiger Reserve areas to increase the total project area from 37,761 sq. kms to 50,000 sq. kms.

'In principle' approval has been granted to proposals from several States. The new Tiger Reserves include:

(i) Anamalai-Parambikulam Wildlife Sanctuaries (Tamil Nadu & Kerala)
(ii) Udanti and Sita Nadi Wildlife Sanctuaries (Chattisgarh)
(iii) Satkosia Wildlife Sanctuary (Orissa)
(iv) Kaziranga National Park (Assam)
(v) Achanakmar Wildlife Sanctuary (Chattisgarh)
(vi) Dandeli Wildlife Sanctuary and Anshi National Park (Karnataka)
(vii) Sanjay National Park and Sanjay Dubri Wildlife Sanctuary (Madhya Pradesh)
(viii) Mudumalai Wildlife Sanctuary (Tamil Nadu)

A total of 8 new Tiger Reserves are proposed with an additional financial implication of Rs. 32.00 crores.
title: New Tiger Reserve Areas

content:
Extending project allowances to ministerial staff to attract talent:

* Class II: Rs 500 per employee per month
* Class III: Rs 350 per employee per month
* Class IV: Rs 200 per employee per month
title: Project Allowance for Ministerial Staff

content:
Field staff serve in remote, difficult areas with endemic diseases and risk of wild animal encounters. Postings are often 'non-family', requiring staff to maintain families elsewhere. They face restrictions on local communities accessing forest resources.

The role of frontline staff in Tiger Reserves differs from that in regular Forest Divisions. Physical assaults on staff are common. Therefore, providing amenities for staff welfare is essential to attract the best talent.
title: Staff Welfare Activities

sub-heading:
Guidelines for Tiger Reserve Management and Conservation.
Fostering Eco-Tourism and Ensuring Financial Support.
title: Project Tiger: Eco-Tourism & Funding

content:
Staff welfare inputs such as residential accommodation for children of frontline staff, supply of kerosene, medicine, field kits, mosquito nets, and torches will be supported.

'Ecotourism' in Tiger Reserves is ecologically sustainable nature-tourism. It is distinct from 'mass tourism', aiming for sustainable, equitable, community-based efforts to improve the living standards of local communities.

Ecotourism will be fostered with financial support via 'soft loans' from Ecodevelopment Committees, in accordance with site-specific 'Ecotourism plans' and carrying capacity in buffer areas.

The core/critical tiger habitats will not be used for tourism, and ongoing tourism activities in such areas should be phased out without affecting corridor value. Development of tourism facilities within buffer zones will continue under Project Tiger.

Opportunities include managing low-cost accommodation, providing guide services, sale outlets, excursions, and ethnic dances.
title: Staff Welfare and Eco-Tourism

content:
Tiger Reserve States must enter into a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the Ministry of Environment and Forests, as per Annexure-1.

Tiger Reserves will receive funding under the Centrally Sponsored Scheme of Project Tiger based on a reserve-specific Tiger Conservation Plan, as required under Section 38-V of the Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972 (amended 2006). This plan should align with NTCA guidelines (Technical Document – NTCA/01/07).

The centrality of Panchayati Raj Institutions should be ensured through consultation for deployment of local workforce, man-animal conflicts, livelihood options, village relocation, and eco-tourism.
The tentative cost table for the scheme is provided at Annexure-II for guidance.
title: Memorandum of Understanding (MOU)

sub_heading:
Agreement between the National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) and the State Government.
Outlines financial assistance for protection and development of tiger reserves, subject to terms and conditions.
Sets forth responsibilities and commitments of the State Government.
title: Annexure-I: MOU Details

content:
The State Government affirms that:

(a) The buffer zone around core/critical tiger habitats will be delineated, and a Tiger Reserve specific Tiger Conservation Plan will be prepared.

(b) Staff vacancies will be filled to ensure effective implementation and field protection.

(c) Funds released by NTCA will be used immediately for approved works, complying with NTCA guidelines.

(d) Estimated costs are based on approved PWD rates of the concerned State.

(e) The Director/Officer Incharge of the Tiger Reserve is empowered to spend the money provided by NTCA for immediate execution, following NTCA and State Government norms.

(f) The proposal shall have reference to the Tiger Conservation Plan, which forms the basis of the APO.
title: State Government Agreements (Article I)

content:
(g) The APO must indicate the location/area of proposed initiatives on a map, along with physical/financial targets and unit rate.

(h) Progress reports should indicate physical achievement (quantity, number, area) and objectives fulfilled.

(i) A year-wise photo catalogue of physical targets shall be maintained for verification.

(j) During execution, details of estimate and man-days shall be displayed near the work site.

(k) Utilisation Certificates showing unspent balance shall be furnished to NTCA annually by 31st May.

(l) Accounts of grants shall be maintained properly and open to NTCA/Audit inspection. Photocopies of measurement books shall be sent to NTCA for construction/habitat works.

(m) Accounts shall be audited by Statutory Audit of the State Government annually, with a certificate sent to NTCA by 31st May.

(n) Funds will be used only for the sanctioned purpose. Diversion requires prior NTCA approval.

(o) Records of assets acquired out of the grant shall be available for audit scrutiny. Assets shall not be disposed of without prior approval.

(p) A statement showing extracts of assets created out of the grants shall be furnished to NTCA annually by 31st May.
title: State Government Agreements (Continued)

content:
NTCA has agreed to provide financial assistance as grant for execution of the following items of work (Rs. in lakhs):

title: NTCA Agreements (Article II)

content:
If there is any delay in execution of the work, the State Govt. shall notify the 
National Tiger Conservation Authority in writing giving the reason for delay. 
If the NTCA feels that work is not progressing according to the work plan, it shall 
be at liberty to withhold the financial assistance or withdraw the financial 
assistance already granted. 
The unspent amount of grant as on the date of 
communication of the decision of the withdrawal of financial assistance by the 
NTCA shall be immediately returned to NTCA.
